title: Trim whitespace
body:
The original issue described extraneous whitespace around cdata
elements, but exploring further finds this is a problem in IDs, links,
summaries etc.

This change trims leading and trailing whitespace only at a field level.
It does not trim whitespace around embedded elements (e.g. hrefs within
html content).

Fixes https://github.com/feed-rs/feed-rs/issues/163

title: Fix decoding regression
body:
Upgrade to quick-xml no longer requires encoding on cdata during
parsing. Added some sample files to validate fix too.

Fixes #172

title: fix: add rfc3339 fix regex to append time
body:
I reported on this a while back, finally debugged the problem, though. Didn't realize DublinCore properties were already being handled in the library. (Deleted my comments in the issue as off-topic.)

The problem was just that the date in the RSS feed was in the format `yyyy-mm-dd`, which doesn't conform to RFC3339.

There are 2 approaches I can see here:
1. Attempt to parse it as `NaiveDate` and then transform it into `DateTime` one way or another.
2. Just add a regex to append midnight UTC if the time part isn't there.

I've opted for approach 2 in this PR.

## Related
* Closes https://github.com/feed-rs/feed-rs/issues/173

---

Note: Literally learned Rust just for this PR, don't be afraid to call out anything dumb and I'll change things up. :+1:

title: Update API doc for quick-xml switch.
body: The feed parser now uses quick-xml instead of xml-rs. Send people to the correct crate from the API documentation; in particular this is necessary to understand the `encoding` feature.

title: RFC 1123 support
body:
Support RFC-1123 date/time format too.

Closes #165

title: Bump MSRV + dependencies
body: Also fixed minor clippy + fmt issues.

title: Fix clippy warnings
body:
While working on `feed-rs` I noticed a number of `cargo clippy` warnings which had trivial fixes, so here's a PR that is 100% the output of committing `cargo clippy --fix`.

The changes only impact test code so feel free to ignore as the only benefit is getting rid of the orange squiggles.

title: When possible, return full URLs for images in Atom feeds
body:
URLs in Atom feeds are allowed to be relative. When using `feed_rs::parser::parse_with_uri`, relative URLs are resolved correctly using `element.xml_base`

https://github.com/feed-rs/feed-rs/blob/138bbf83bead06e4eb4fb8a84cd4fa1c72056c29/feed-rs/src/parser/atom/mod.rs#L224-L225

https://github.com/feed-rs/feed-rs/blob/138bbf83bead06e4eb4fb8a84cd4fa1c72056c29/feed-rs/src/model.rs#L633-L637

however images don't get the same treatment

https://github.com/feed-rs/feed-rs/blob/138bbf83bead06e4eb4fb8a84cd4fa1c72056c29/feed-rs/src/parser/atom/mod.rs#L217-L219

which is a bit inconvenient as knowledge of the base URL needs to be threaded through to wherever these relative URLs are used.

To remedy this I've added a failing test and modified `handle_image` to first attempt to parse the URL with the base and fallback to the raw value. This should be a non-breaking change as downstream consumers will have had to handle both relative and full URLs for these fields anyway.

----

Fun story - the feed that surfaced this discrepancy was `https://www.tbray.org/ongoing/ongoing.atom` and I wasn't about to question Tim Bray's XML 😂.

title: Drop empty enclosures
body:
The Matrix blog includes `<content:encoded/>` which was parsed as an empty string. The parser will now just return None in this case.

Fixes #155

title: Test for fuzz debug_assert
body:
The failure in url has been fixed with a recent round of dependency updates.

Including the original fuzz regression test case.

Fixes #141

title: Allow for CDATA in <dc:creator> and <category> for RSS2 feeds
body:
Hi there! Thanks for a great library ❤️.

As a side project I've recently been putting together a RSS crawler using `feed-rs` among other things, and I've noticed that on several feeds (e.g. `http://feeds.feedburner.com/TheWirecutter`) I end up with categories and authors as empty strings. Turns out this is due to those feeds using `CDATA` in the relevant tags, which causes `child_as_text` to return an empty string.

I've included a failing test case and what I think might be an appropriate fix, however it has the downside of dropping any errors from `children_as_string` on the floor. Happy to make any adjustments if this is something you'd like to merge.
